summary: This is an email chain from July 6, 2020, between FBI personnel discussing the status of digital evidence processing in the Epstein case. It details the number of devices, specific items like servers and DVRs from Epstein's properties, and the technical challenges and progress in data recovery and export.

persons.name: SSA - FBI New York
persons.context: The recipient of the email chain, being updated on the status of digital evidence processing.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The primary sender providing detailed technical updates on processing digital evidence from Epstein's properties, including servers and DVRs.

connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Professional correspondence within the FBI regarding the technical status of evidence processing in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Digital Evidence Status Update
events.description: FBI forensic examiners provide an update on the processing of 55 digital evidence items from the Epstein investigation, noting technical issues with servers and DVRs and promising data recovery efforts.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: A total of 55 digital evidence items were accounted for in the Epstein investigation as of July 2020.
Two servers from 'the Island' (likely Little St. James) were still being processed due to mechanical difficulties.
Three DVRs (one from a New York apartment and two from the Island) were under examination, with data carving attempted to recover deleted files.
Files from 39 items had been exported for review by the Southern District of New York, limited to documents, spreadsheets, emails, and presentations, excluding images and videos.
The correspondence reveals ongoing, detailed forensic work on Epstein's digital evidence well after his death.
